title: E and G forces on two particles

content.question: Two particles, of charge <math alttext="positive e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>e</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="negative e" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>e</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, each have a mass of <math alttext="1.6 times 10 to the negative 19 power, kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.6</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>19</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The particles are held a fixed distance apart. How do the magnitudes of the electrostatic force and the gravitational force between the particles compare?

choices.label: They are about the same because the masses are of the same magnitude as the charges.
They are about the same because both forces are inversely proportional to the square of the separation distance.
The electrostatic force is greater because the electrostatic force constant is larger than the gravitational force constant.
The electrostatic force is greater because it is repulsive while the gravitational force is attractive.

content.answer: The electrostatic force is greater because the electrostatic force constant is larger than the gravitational force constant.
